title: 106_s2776
content: The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" is also known as the Act. It increases the limitation on charitable deduction for contributions for medical research. The "Medical Research Investment Act of 2000" increases the charitable deduction limit for medical research contributions to 80% of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year. The charitable deduction limit for medical research contributions is increased to 80% of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year. The charitable deduction limit for medical research contributions is increased to 80% of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year. Contributions exceeding this limit can be carried over as medical research contributions in the following 10 years. The charitable deduction limit for medical research contributions is increased to 80% of the taxpayer's contribution base for any taxable year. Contributions exceeding this limit can be carried over as medical research contributions in the following 10 years. In the case of a medical research contribution of capital gain property, subsection (e)(1) applies. The term 'medical research contribution' refers to a charitable donation designated for conducting medical research to organizations described in specific clauses. The term 'medical research contribution' is defined as a charitable donation for medical research organizations as specified in the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments have been made to sections of the Code to include medical research contributions. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding "or a medical research contribution" in certain sections. The amendments made by this section apply to contributions made in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000, and to contributions made on or before December 31, 2000, to the extent that a deduction would be allowed under section 170 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. SEC. 3. Treatment of certain incentive stock options. Treatment of incentive stock options under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include an exception for certain medical research stock transfers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt medical research stock transfers from certain provisions regarding incentive stock options. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt medical research stock transfers from certain provisions regarding incentive stock options within the same taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts medical research stock transfers from certain provisions on incentive stock options in the same taxable year. Medical research stock transfers meeting certain requirements are exempt from specific provisions on incentive stock options in the same taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to transfers of stock made after the date of the enactment of this Act.
